header.title: New Writings Of Rav Ashlag Class #8

central_thesis: The fundamental thesis is that everything in reality, including what is perceived as evil or damaging, possesses an inherent right to exist as part of the Creator's perfect design. These 'imperfections' are not flaws but rather transitional stages in a divinely guided, gradual evolutionary process towards ultimate good and completeness, akin to the ripening of a fruit. Humanity's role is not to eradicate perceived evil but to 'repair and guide' it towards its intended perfected state, understanding that the Creator permits nothing to be destroyed but only transformed.

structure_content.summary: This section establishes the core principle that all aspects of creation, irrespective of perceived goodness or evil, have a divine right to exist. It explicitly forbids the complete destruction or removal of anything from the world, positing that humanity's duty is to mend and direct things towards goodness, thereby inferring the Creator's inherent perfection in all creation.

This chapter emphasizes the theological imperative not to find fault in any part of creation, as such an act would implicitly 'give a bad name' to the Creator. It reveals that creation was not instantaneously completed but designed for a process of gradual development and evolution, from a state of initial absence to maximum growth, justifying temporary imperfections as developmental stages.

This section explains that what is perceived as 'damaging' or 'evil' is merely an indicator of a transitional phase in the evolutionary process, drawing an analogy to the bitterness of an unripe fruit. It cautions against judging these phases as inherently bad or faulty, advocating for a deeper understanding of the ongoing process towards completeness.

The text criticizes 'false world reformers' who view humanity and creation as flawed machines requiring removal or extermination of 'broken parts.' It argues that this approach stems from a misunderstanding of the Creator's design, which guards all creation and permits only transformation towards good, not destruction. These reformers are seen as attempting to thwart the divine evolutionary plan.

This concluding section reiterates that 'evil qualities' are not meant to be eradicated but are destined to transform and ripen into good and beneficial attributes, fulfilling the Creator's original conception. The analogy of a fruit ripening on a tree illustrates that these qualities are simply undergoing a necessary period of development until their inherent goodness and sweetness are fully manifested.

key_concepts.definition: The fundamental principle that every component of reality, regardless of its apparent nature (good, bad, or evil), is divinely ordained and has an inherent right to exist within the Creator's plan; therefore, its destruction is forbidden.

The concept that all creation, in its totality and various stages, is perfect from the Creator's perspective. Perceived flaws or imperfections are not actual defects but rather temporary states within an ongoing, guided process of development.

The process by which creation unfolds and matures over time, moving from an initial state of incompleteness (or 'absence') through various 'transition phases' towards its ultimate, perfected form, rather than being created in a final, static state.

Humanity's ethical and spiritual responsibility is not to eliminate or condemn perceived evils, but to actively participate in their amelioration and direction towards goodness, facilitating their natural progression within the divine evolutionary scheme.

A critical term for those who, through ignorance of the divine plan, seek to forcibly 'exterminate' or remove elements of creation deemed 'bad' or 'damaging,' failing to understand that such elements are meant for transformation, not eradication.

A metaphor illustrating the transformation of initially 'bitter' or 'evil' qualities into 'good' and 'beneficial' ones through a necessary period of development, much like an unripe fruit matures into a sweet one, revealing its inherent perfection.

practical_system.description: The 'practical system' presented is primarily philosophical and perceptual, influencing the practitioner's internal state and approach to reality rather than outlining specific rituals or spellcraft. It mandates a radical shift in perspective: instead of perceiving evil or difficulty as something to be fought or destroyed, one must recognize its inherent right to exist as a phase in divine evolution. The operative mechanic is 'repair and guide,' which implies mindful interaction, positive influence, and patience with processes of growth and transformation. This translates into a commitment to internal and external work that fosters development, integration, and the revelation of inherent goodness in all things. It's an internal alchemy of perspective that underpins any external magical work, ensuring that actions are aligned with the Creator's evolutionary design rather than misguided attempts at eradication.

relevant_quotes.text: Everything that exists in reality, whether good or bad, or even the most evil and damage-causing thing in the world, has the right to exist, to the degree that destroying it and removing it completely from the world is forbidden.

Rather, our duty is only to repair or fix it and guide it towards goodness. For, even a casual observation of any sort at the work of creation that lies before us is enough to infer the high degree of perfection of Him who has created it.

Therefore, we have to understand and to take great care that we do not find faults in any part of creation, declaring it to be superfluous and unnecessary, because this amounts to giving bad name, heaven forbid, on Him who created it.
Thus, if we feel that some particular part of Creation is damaging or evil, this only indicates that this particular part is in a transition phase in terms of its evolution.
This is the sole purpose of these world reformers: to exterminate all that is bad and damaging in the human species.
By that point, those very same evil qualities have transformed and become good and beneficial, as the Creator had originally conceived of them.

This is like a fruit sitting on the branches of a tree, waiting and counting the days and months that it must go through until its ripening process is completed, which is when its taste and sweetness would be revealed to everyone.

critical_analysis.relevance: This teaching from Rav Ashlag presents a profoundly non-dualistic perspective on good and evil, deeply rooted in Kabbalistic thought, specifically within the framework of 'Tikkun' (repair) and the emanation of creation. It is highly relevant for practitioners of Western Esotericism and Occultism who grapple with the nature of challenging experiences, shadow work, or the 'darker' aspects of self and cosmos. Unlike many dualistic magical systems that seek to banish or destroy 'evil' influences, Ashlag's work advocates for a process of integration and transformation, seeing all phenomena as stages towards divine perfection. This aligns with advanced magical philosophies that emphasize alchemical transmutation rather than mere opposition, offering a nuanced understanding of 'qlippothic' or challenging energies as part of a larger evolutionary process. It contextualizes suffering or 'negative' manifestations not as an error in creation but as an essential phase of development, encouraging patience, understanding, and active 'repair' rather than simplistic eradication. This perspective challenges conventional morality and provides a robust metaphysical basis for ethical magical practice focused on integration and holistic growth.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes advanced students and practitioners of Kabbalah, Hermeticism, and other forms of Western Esotericism, particularly those interested in the metaphysical reconciliation of good and evil, the philosophy of divine emanation, and the practical application of Tikkun. It would appeal to Chaos Magicians seeking a robust philosophical framework for understanding reality's fluidity and transformation, as well as those engaged in depth psychology or spiritual alchemy. The text is suitable for individuals who have moved beyond rudimentary magical operations and are seeking a more comprehensive and non-dualistic understanding of cosmic processes and humanity's role within them.
